p: The reductive acetogenesis is an accepted mechanism of H 2 utilization that coexists with methanogenesis in the rumen [ 129, 130]. Acetate, the end product of this reaction, has the additional advantage of being a source of energy for the animal. However, acetogens are less numerous in the rumen environment and less efficient than methanogens in respect of competing for reducing equivalents. Therefore, it is needed to increase the number of acetogenic bacteria in the rumen, which compete with methanogens for hydrogen, as a result of CH 4 reduction. Kim et al. [ 131] and Martin et al. [ 23] stated that CH 4 production was reduced with the dietary supplementation of acetogen probiotics in ruminants.
